Chicago Feb. 11th 1864
There begin a new volume of my diary.
We had a good breakfast this morn. I bought this book we marched down to the depot and got aboard the cars. (near Janesville) and were soon rolling on.
At a little village called Palestine, a whole school of children came to see us.  Some of the boys had a snow balling frolic with the little chaps altogether it was quite a lively scene. It is dark

and we are about eight miles from Janesville
Friday Feb. 12th
Arrived(?) at Portage City find the cars stopped. They were intending to make ______ there anything _________________ fort Col. obst___ took the liberty. to  find them under arrest and telegraphed back to the superintendent of the road who replied that we were detained without his knowledge. We therefore soon proceeded forward arrived in La Crosse.

abut half past three p.m. After some trouble we got into Sleighs and arrive in Wenona about midnight. Here a     entertainment was waiting our arrival and the ___ ____ ___ 
Oh!  Heavens!
Of course there was near eairly some making cheering etc
Saturday Feb. 13th
We left Wenona late in the forenoon. At Memiska(?) we were told that the ice was impassible

from there to Wabash but we resolved to pass it any how. We followed up some times on the islands some times on the ice until we found ourselves on the Wisconsin side of the river and the water was open ne(?) at last found a ferry and crossed part way on the ice and part way on the boat. When we arrived in Wabashar there had been no preparation made for our comfort during the 
[MARGINALIA:  only 25 cts at Wabashan for sleeping on the floor]

night so we put up at Hotel's and private houses. Some of the boys have a row with a copprhead
Sunday Feb. 14th
We have a very pleasant drive from Wabashan to Hasting. Stopped at Red Wing had a splendid dinner. Noble little town! The girls ran out and kissed the soldiers as they came into town.  Oh it was a glorious sight!  Leaving Red Wing some time in the

afternoon and arrived at in Hastings about eight P.M. Here we were entertained well at the Hotels.
Monday Feb. 15th
Arose this morn. and after some delay we were furnished with a good breakfast.  At the breakfast table I heard an old tosser(?) say that he drank horse water yesterday and that it made him sick he added that hereafter he intended to take his whiskey clear.  I looked at him

and soon came to the conclusion that if water ever hurt him it was because it lay on his brain. We moved on about noon and arrived in St. Paul late in the afternoon. The city seemed to have gone insane.  We were enthusiastically welcomed by the citizens. But best of all was a meeting with Jarves(?). Oh! he and his ____ must be happy with all their privations; if they are not happy I am sure it would not

1864
take much to make them so.
Tuesday Feb. 16th
I left Jarves residence early in the morning and went to the ___ where the rest(or regt)(?) was quartered. I there received a letter from Pelatiah and one from Melissa, I got a thirty days furlough about noon. I then went to the quarters of the Provost March, Charley Graves then went with me to see a german natural artist.

never saw a finer fellow in my life. His pictures are excellent - After I had returned to the quarters, I met Eancas(?) Stubbs, and of course must talk with him a while. I was afterwards taking with Jonathan we have and he "flanked me" I next went over with Eancas and paid a short visit to Jarve - after which we retired.
Wednesday Feb. 17th
I arose and started to the depot in such

haste that I left my dress coat behind. I was not soon enough to get aboard of the passenger train but I managed to get a ride in a freight car without cost. I visited Ann C. I then finished a letter which I had commenced yesterday to Pelatiah - Wrote a note to Charley Graves to have my dress coat taken care of

after which I went to the Post Office. I have been having a good time with the children.
Thursday Feb. 18th
I arose in the morn and having washed and breakfasted, I set down to solid enjoyment. I wrote to John Buckelen, after which I read Popes Eloisa to Abelard(?), played with the Children. Miss Menard asked me to take a Philipine with her but I was so green that I did not know what it was; but having now found out, I shall try

to not be so ignorant in the future.
Friday Feb. 19th
After breakfast I started up to see the folks.  Stopped at Wale's and took dinner. I then went on and came to Neds school he then went with me we had supper at Mr. Overlocks. After which we went on up to Samsons. Where we are to night. Ned played some on violin for me.

Saturday Feb. 20th
I took a walk with Ned, after which he and I went over to Milhollins. We had an excelent time with the boys - and I shall not deny that Kate looks well, though she is not conscious of the fact.
Sunday Feb. 21st
Henkle and Ned played on their instruments. I had a long talk with J.M. in the eve subject religion
Monday Feb. 22d
Talked with J.M. on

various topics. I heard Kate make a few sensible remarks about the Indian war.
I went over to Clarkson Thomas house where I found Uncle Sturdevant(?) - I had a very long and highly interesting conversation with the old man.
Tuesday Feb. 23d
I talked with uncle Sturdvant and Clark for a while in the morning. I then went over to Samsons. I wrote some in a letter to Melissa - I feel very sad in consequence

of the ignorance which I fear will always prevail in Samson's family
Wednesday Feb. 24th
I helped Samson get a load of hay from the meadow. After which I went over to Milhollins. Talked with J.M.
Thursday Feb. 25th
Talked with J.M. We went to see Irenius(?) Atkinson played a game of chess with him. We then returned to My
Kate will be a noble woman some time

Friday Feb. 26th
Ned came up to Ms and I went down to Overlocks with him. Mrs. Overlock preached me a long sermon in favor of adventism.
Saturday Feb. 27th
Ned and I visited uncle Sturdevant. we had an interesting conversation with him. We then proceeded up to Rothmear's(?) Prairie where there was to be a party. and Oh! Ye Gods! as might be expected it was one more sad proof that all is vanity(?) Amen unto the Joy of God.

We did not break up the concern untill Sabath hours. So it was very late when we laid us down to sleep in Neds bed.
Sunday Feb. 28th
After prayer and breakfast, Ned and I set out for Minneapolis. We called upon uncle Sturdivant and talked with him a spell. From there we proceeded on our journey conversing on the science of drawing correct conclusions from any given point in human nature. Or to be more plain, the science of taking a few words uttered

by any person in covnersation and thererom building out the whole train of said persons ideas.  We arrived at Ams C.B. and here we are tonight.
Monday Feb. 29th
We left Anns about ten oclock A.m. and arrived at Jarves room about 2 P.M.  Jarve was gone school. returned about four after supper We went to the quarters of the Provost Guard. Returned and here we are to night with Jarve.
I admire him and Carrie so very much.

March 1st 1864
Tuesday Mary 1st
Left ___P and about eight o'clock in the morning and arrived in Hudson about 3 P.M. Found Uncle Joseph and mother well and doing well.
Wednesday March 2
Mother and Ned and I went to see a house belonging to Uncle.  We learned that Uncle was satisfied with the ____ arrangement which made me very glad. After dinner

I read "Garons" (Garrisons?) then some mens prayers. Also a little in Shakespeare.
Thursday March 3d
Uncle and Ned left this morning for St. Paul. Mother and I went to the Daguerrian rooms and I had a couple of ambratypes taken, one for Mother and one for Melissa. What pleased me best was that a young lady officiated and she was a perfect little angel. Albeit there was a "laughing devil in her eye." I was

almost smitten, I confess it. I will not here put in a "dish of dandelion greens" but I will say, that in the afternoon I went to Willow river to get some willows for baskets. Read English Bards and Scottish hebiers(?)
Friday March 4th
I read in Don Juan nearly  all day. The rest of the day I spent in reading the N.Y. Tribune. I also read a little in Blairs lectures. I believe I have read almost too much today.

Saturday March 5th
I helped mother sweep out a  ______
After which I read Don Juan also newspapers
Sunday March 6th 1864
I read the Siege of Corinth the Waltz" and a carto of Don Juan. I also read some Blairs lectures in S___ ____ of the U.S. and In Bangor's(?) Pilgrims ____
Sunday was thus passed off most pleasantly.
Monday March 7th
Uncle returned I read in the N.Y. Ledger in the ______________ and

in Don Juan also in Benjamin Pilgrims progress
Tuesday March 8th
I read on Don Juan
I wrote to the A____ and I took a walk
_____ said to the ___ of some one I ____
Wednesday March 9th
I finished reading Don Juan. And now I will say that I was induced to put off going back to ST. Paul yesterday and now I have reason to repeat it. I do not believe that

I ever postponed a thing without having occasion infrequently to use it. I shall hereafter do whatever is to be done at the prefer time
Thursday March 10th
I helped Uncle and mother move then went to St. Paul, where I arrived about eight P.M. found that Jarve had come up on the Prairie.
Friday March 11th
I went over to the Provost Guard to see

the boys, found Charley Graves Sr. - In the afternoon I took the cars for St. Anthony from thense I went over to Minneapolis found Hezekiah at home. and I had a splendid time - I purchased Longfellows poems.
Saturday March 12th
Hezekiah and I walked out and enjoyed ourselves. Jarve came along about noon, and we read the Song of Hiawatha
Sunday March 13th
Walked out in the

forenoon - read the Song of Hiawatha. I am not supping this evening. The reason is __________ Jarve ____ to day _____ to a person who ____  I could ___- not think of ____ during this life.
Monday March 14th
I went with Jarve to the depot. We had a good conversation on the cold subject which once was interesting to me, and still has a Mel___ of interest

to me.  Ned came up in the evening. We had a very Good time.
Tuesday March 15th
Went down to town, got a newspaper, read it, talked with Hezekiah and Charley (?).  Ned went back to St. Paul this eve.
Wednesday March 16
Went to town and bought a newspaper as I came along some of the waving(?) ladies invited me to go to school with her. of course I could not resist the

temptation. When I got back I found Brown at H's.  read the newspaper, then talked with H and B. Split wood all of the afternoon.
Thursday March 17th
Went down to the Fort and a miserable place it is. The weather is cold.
Friday March 18th
The weather continues cold. Lay around the quarters. Read "Paradise and the Peri."

Saturday March 19th
Boys kick things around. It is about as annoying to me as anything I have seen in the army.
Sunday March 20th
Hezekiah Brown and I left Ft. Snelling and went up to H's where I found Ned and he and I went on to N. W's. We had a good time on the way.
Monday March 21st
Returned to Ft. Snelling - got a pass and went to St. Paul. met

1864
A.M. K on the way went down and am with Jarve tonight.
Tuesday March 22nd
I went with Jarve to the Commercial College. I think one of the specimens of Mr. Haskills drawing is the best I ever saw of any bodys. I returned to the Fort - found considerable excitement owing to one of Co. C of of our Regt ____ing just leaped off of the bluffs cause said to be delerium tremens - I received

a good letter from Melissa - answered it
Wednesday March 23d
Mr. Bert the man who leaped off the Bluff yesterday died this morning - Berdan and I walked out to Minnehaha this morning - We enjoyed ourselves well - I like Berdan extremely well - I offered to reenlist today provided I could be transferred to the Cavelry - this was denied me therefore

I do not consider my-self under any obligation to enter the service at all.
Thursday March 24th
Accompanied the remains of the unfortunate soldier who destroyed himself to their last resting place.
Ned came down and is with me tonight - we reviewed some old letters together. We had a dress parade this evening - did pretty well considering that we are out of practice

Friday March 25th
Ned and I left this morning for Minneapolis when we arrived w found mother there. Stayed about three hours and returned to the Fort.  Went on dress parade - Charley Berdan came arouund and talked with us a long time this eve I studied grammer a little this evening
Saturday March 26th 
Study Grammer. The papers bring an account of the

capture of a rebel fort on the Red River.
Sunday March 27th
Study grammer. Took a walk with Ole Gillmen and Andrew Bayer, after which I wrote a burlesque letter for Ole.
Monday March 28th
Ole and I went up to Minneapolis. Tried to get a bounty on Oles first enlistment but failed.  I then went up to Hezekiahs found Ned and Samson there - Studiedd grammer a little in

the evening. It has been raining nearly all day.  Minnesota need rain badly and I hope it will let up this spring, a few more ____ days as this would open the river
Tuesday March 29th
Ned started up river this morning. I studied Grammer, and sawed wood this fore noon, and in the afternoon we returned to the fort
Wednesday March 30th
Study Grammer and

walk about
Thursday March 31st
I read twenty pages of grammer then turned to the questions for review and answered every question. Walked about some to day
Friday April 1st 1864
I read 10 pages of grammer and answered every question. Walk about enjoy myself well
Saturday April 2d
I am twenty two (22) years old to day and what do I know?  Also what

have I accomplished?  The answers nothing.  Hezekiah and I went up to Minneapolis. Henkle and T.J. come down to day and I accompanied them home.
Sunday April 3rd
Billy is indeed very low but he keeps cheerful. I left Millhollins a little afternoon and arrived at Minneapolis at Seven P.M.  I will stay here to night
Monday April 4th 
Returned to the fort. Studied grammer. Walked out in the

evening. Danced some this eve.
Tuesday April 5th
Study Grammer walk about and attend church in the evening
Wednesday April 6th 
Study grammer and walk about went over and talked with HSA Keniston this eve
Thursday April 7th
Study grammer and walk about. the boys and Lt. Col. Adams are now at Luards(?) points. My curses on these Contemptable Officers

Friday April 8th
Study Grammer. ten lodges of Indians were brought here to day from the frontier.
Saturday April 9th
I had a chill and fever. My right lung is very sore
Sunday April 10th
My fever has subsided a little. My lung however is very sore.  I was stuck in the quarters until after April 13th when I was removed to the

Hospital I lay here until April 19th which is to day and I am well enough now to resume my diary.  I walked out this morning wrote to mother.
April 20th
I walked about during the forenoon with Chal (Charley) Graves. I am recovering rapidly
Thursday April 21st.
Read and walk about enjoy myself pretty well. We had a big review and inspection by the great Gen. Lilly who knows 
[Marginalia]:
during time I was in the hospital I read a cousin marrying novel which greatly disgusted me

about as much as a Ft. Gibralter marking.
Friday April 22d
I wrote to Melissa and studied Grammer, besides I saw my esteemed friend A.L.M. Decker.  He gave me his photograph - I had but a short time to talk with him as he left for Madison Wisconsin after I first saw him. I also had the pleasure of seeing an old friend A.M. Keniston of the 4th Minn. He also soon after started for

St Paul. I believe his Regt. leaves for the front tomorrow.
Saturday April 23d
I read a little in Harpers Weekly and in the Bible - I walked about some
Sunday April 24th 1864
Take a walk morning and evening - I got discharged from the hospital I studied Grammer
Monday April 25th
Went on an unsuccessful fishing expedition, found myself rather weak to stand and hold a hook - studied

1864
grammer. Talked with Imson and Baniler(?) on literature.
Tuesday April 26th
Studied grammer. Ned come down, and Hezekiah and I took a long and very pleasant walk. In the afternoon the Regt had a drill but as I am not on duty now Ned and I took a pleasant walk and conversation.
Wednesday April 27th
Ned returned home and Hezekiah and I accompanied him as far as Minnehaha Creek; returned to

the fort and studied grammer - I feel quite sorrowful as the day of parting with my comrades approaches.  I have now got the address of most of them and have agreed to exchange photographs with them.
Thursday April 28th
An order is published in the papers this morning to the effect that all the men who left the state with the regt shall be discharged tomorrow and the remained to be formed into an independent battalion and forwarded to

Washington at once.
I studied Grammer, and took a walk alone this morning.  The Regt was reviewed in the afternoon by Gov. Miller and Gen. Sibly
Friday April 29th
Capt. Ball promised to give me a letter of recommendation before he leaves. This I trust will be of great advantage to me at some future time.  We had a slight shower this morn remained during the day I spent

1864
the day very happily - study grammer and walk about. Took a walk in the eve with __ Larson and had a long conversation with Charley Berdan after dark.
Saturday April 30th
Study grammer. And walk about enjoy myself exceeding well. Charley Berdan and I took a most pleasant walk in the evening. We had an interesting conversation. I confess I do admire Charley.
Sunday May 1st 1864
Windy weather and very cool for this time of the year

Studied grammer and walk about every thing is dull - yet as the grass and trees are becoming robed in green I spent some happy hours every day. A few young flowers are starting from the ground which adds materially to the pleasures of life. I received a letter from A.B.M.D. attempted to answer it but found I was not in a writing mode.
Monday May 2d
Spend the day as usual studying

grammer and walking about
May 3d Tuesday
After walking around in the forenoon, H and I left for Minneapolis in the afternoon. I was quite tired when we arrived at our place of destination. I studied grammer during the forenoon also I received a letter from Jarve and answered it besides finishing my letter to Decker.

Wednesday 4th
Returned from Minneapolis. We voted our company fund to the Sanitary commission. I have studied grammer considerable today. I also spent some time in reviewing and in walking around.
Thursday May 5th
The boys were discharged. Ned came down.
Friday May 6th
Net returned. Capt. Ball gave me a recommend.  I studied grammer

Jim Imson and I propose to watch and see what will happen in our armies to day.
Saturday May 7th
Berdan and I went down to St. Paul, had our pictures taken. Spent the afternoon with Jarve. The papers bring the news of fighting in Virginia. I stay with Jarve to night.
Sunday May 8th 
Ft. Snelling
Jarve walked up this side of the City

City with me. Nothing much
Monday May 9th
The papers bring news of continued fighting. I study grammer.
Tuesday May 10th
The papers keep telling of fighting all round. I study grammer. Jim Imson and I take a walk and pick flowers.  An election of Lieutentants resulting in the election of Henston for first and OBrien

for second.
Wednesday May 11th
Got through the grammer to day and continued reviewing. I shall pay particular attention to punctuation / 
May 12th Thursday.
Still account come of hard fighting. I study punctuation to day. I took a walk in company with Hezekiah just after dinner and another this eve in company with C.O. Thomas
Friday May 13th
The papers bring glorious news from the wings(?)

Jim Imson, Hezekiah and I tool a walk, and gathered some flowers this forenoon.  Berdan and I had a pleasant walk and interesting conversation this eve. Next Charley Grave and I took a walk and had a long conversation. I received a letter from P. to day. I continue to study punctuation.
Saturday May 14th
took a walk in the morning with Jim Imson and in the evening with Charley Berdan. After that I

had a long gas with Charley Grave. I studied punctuation and Prosody. Papers bring good news of successes in Georgia and Virginia.
Sunday May 15th
Jim and I take a walk in the morn and afternoon. In the evening Berdan, Imson and I took a bath. I study punctuation.
Monday 16th
Hezekiah and I take a walk in the morn and Charley Grave

and I in the eve. I studied prosody and punctuation a little to day. We drew our arms and accoutrements to day.
Tuesday 17th May
We left the fort early this morning. The weather was very warm and the roads dusty. We arrived in St. Paul about 11 oclock. I saw Jarve and bid him good bye. I got a dozzen photographs.  Well, well, we have had big drunken

rows. I am on guard this eve. I saw an attempt to violate Charley Berdans orders when he was on post. It terminated as might be expected.
Charly is a noble soldier and has strength to back his will.  I perceive that we have not such men as those of the old 1st.
We are on the steamer Northern Belle; Merily we glide down the river. The day is beautiful and the scenery the "docilest(?) that earth ever gave."  Who would believe that our mission is one of

death.
Wednesday May 18th 1864.
I was called up at midnight to relieve corporal May. Continued on duty until 6 A.M. We just at the foot of Lake Pepin when day dawned.  Oh! the scenery is so lovely along this river at this time of the year; but I was rather too sleepy to enjoy it well.  We arrived in LaCrosse about 3 P.M.  It is now about 5. We leave at eight for the east.  I expect the boys will have another drink today.

Thursday May 19th 
We left LaC'rosse at 8:30 P.M. I soon after fell asleep. In the morning, we were at Minnesota Junction. Here we staid until one P.M. Charley Berdan and I had a very good time admiring the scenery along the road. I love Charley more every day I am with him. I was glad to see Jarve admire him so much.
Friday May 20th
We left Chicago at ten P.M. I soon after fell asleep when I awoke it was day light. We arrived in

Ft. Wayne about an hour later.  In the afternoon we were delayed several hours owing to the breaking of three coal cars on the road ahead of us.  We did not arrive in Pittsburg until about one a.m. on the morn of the 21st.
Pittsburg May 21st Saturday
We had breakfast at the volunteer refreshment rooms.  My admiration of this city was greatly increased by observing that its inhabitants are nearly all laborers.

I always admired it, but now I do admire it more. After breakfast we visited the rolling mills, and afterward, the Fort Pitt Iron Foundry. Here we saw the famous 20 inch Dalghreen Gun. It is truly a monster.  We also saw, while near the rolling mills, two monitors in course of construction: one, the Manayunk, was fast approaching completion. In short my walk has paid me well. I hope I may have the oportunity to visit

this city some time when I can go when and where I please and return when I am satisfied. Oh! I must yet travel!
The following are the dimensions of the Great Gun
Height rough  170,000

  "      finished   115200.

Length  rough    300 inches

"      finished    243-1/2

Diameter Max rough    66 "

  "             "  finished    64"
   "         Min   rough     48"
   "           "  finished      24 "

Bore                                20"
Depth of bore    210"

Solid Shat(?) 1,000 lbs
Charge of powder 80 "
In the afternoon we had a second visit to the Great Gun. We then ascended a hill commanding a view of the greater part of the City. We proceeded to another hill whence we could obtain a view of the rest of the City. Thence we returned to our halting place. We are now (8.30 P.M.) on the cars and about starting for Harrisburg.

Sunday May 22d 1864
We arrived in Harrisburg this morning, Had breakfast at the soldiers retreat. Learning that we are not likely to leave immediately paid a visit to the state Capital.  There I saw some guns which were taken at Cerro Gordo, also some British and revolutionary pieces.  The Capitol grounds are well laid out and very beautiful but not more so than other places of the kind.  The City, on the whole, is rather more attractive than

is common with Cities of its size.  After considerable delay we finally get on our way. We were attached to a heavy freight train and consequently moved slow.
Monday May 23d
We arrived in Baltimore some time after sun rise this morning; had breakfast at the soldier's rest. About 10 oclock we started for Washington where we arrived in the afternoon. After supper I paid a visit to the capitol. There I saw the famous bronze door, It is a sight worth a visit

even though it involved a journey of a thousand miles. I cannot describe it. How could I? when it would take five years of reading to enable me to understand all that it represents unless my reading was solely devoted to that object.
Tuesday May 24th
I wrote to Melissa and sent my photograph to Cornelia. After that Hezekiah and I visited the Capitol. We examined more manntely(?)  the bronze door I

found that with the exception of the wreathe it was easily understood. In the afternoon Berdan, Imson and I visited the Senate also the House but the topics of discussion here not very interesting. In the evening several of us took a walk in the Capitol grounds.
Wednesday May 25th I wrote a note to Jarve. Berdan, Imson, Hezekiah, and I visited the Botanical Gardens on the Smithsonians Institute.

after dinner we visited the Patent Office. There is plenty of material in these institutions to keep one individual studying a thousand years.
Thursday May 26th
I wrote to mother, received a letter from Decker and answered it.  Rain is falling. We visited the capitol this eve and here I will ennumerate the pictures and statues in the dome gallery. Just above

door of the main entrance is a group of statuary representing the Landing of Enrico in 1620. Passing around the gallery to the right we behold the following in regular succession
Landing of Columbus Oct 1492. Embarcation of the Pilgrims from DelftHaren in Holland July 21st 1620. Bust of Hon. Fred. P. Stanton. Horation stone _____. Treaty of William Penn 1682. Bust of T. Kasciuszko. Gen Washington resigning

his commission to Congress Annapolis Md. Dec. 23d 1783. Statue of George Washington with the following inscription: The General Assembly of the Commonwealth of Virginia have caused this statue to be erected as a monument of affection and gratitude to George Washington who, ___ting to the endowment of the Hero the virtues of the Patriot and exerting both in establishing the Liberties of his Country has rendered his name

dear to his Fellow Citizens, and given the World an immortal example of true Glory. Done in the year of Christ One thousand seven hundred and eighty eight. and ____ year of the Commonwealth _____
Next following the Inrren(?) of Lord Cornwallis York Tosn VA Oct 19th 1781 and three statues which are too deep for me. Next Grarp(?) of Stationary A. Capellum  T Representation of the Great Massacre at James Town CA 1606 Surrender of Gen. Bar-

gayr Saratoga N.Y. Oct. 1777. Declaration of Independence July 4th 1776. Philadelphia PA Enrico Cansini(?) of Verona ____.
Baptism of Pochahontas Jamestown VA 1613. Busts of Hon. Mr. Colfax Senator Chandler and Rev. Dr. Samson. Discovery of the Mississippi River ____ 1541 Bust of LaSales. In the Center of the Gallery are the following pictures Hon. Lahngler Colfax Hon. Owen

Lovejoy, Washington. Before York Town giving orders to commence the entrenchments accompanied by LaFayette Hamilton, Knox, Lincoln and Rockhambear + Jackson. John Adams, John Q. Adams, Fillmore. Gen Cass, Senator Preston, James B. Polk. Visiting the statue of Washington in the Capitol Ground last eve and also just a few minutes before visiting the gallery we noticed an immense swarm of minute

insects continually hovering over the head the great Hero and on last eave little birds came and caught flies at the statue.
Friday May 27th
We marched early this morning; crossed the Potomac on Long Bridge and encamped on Arlington hights near Ft. Albany far from the Contraband Camp.
Saturday May 28th 64.
I was one of the non commissioned

officers appointed to drill recruits to day. I find a great difference between executing a command myself and telling others to do it. I had a very interesting conversation with Berdan and Imson this evening.
Sunday May 29th
Inspection this morning. study grammer and tactics awhile then Imson, Hezekiah and myself went strawberrying. afterward we had dress parade. a very insignificant affair.

Monday May 30th
We marched this morning to Alexandria where we lay until evening then we got aboard the transport Emmilie, Steamed down to near Agria Creek here we anchored for the night.
Tuesday May 31st
We steamed down the Potomac and Chesapeake. anchored near the mouth of the York River. I have been reflecting upon the pleasures that such a course as this would have given me when

I was fifteen years of age but now I see that I am an old man at twenty two.
1864
Wednesday June 1st
Steamed up the York River passed York Town, West Point and entered the Pammunkey.  Of all crooked rivers this beats 36 miles by river to gain 14 by land. We landed at the White House and here we are now.  All kind of rumors about. nothing reliable from the front. Bathed in

the Pammunkey swam across and back which required about a miles swimming.  I find that I can't swim as I could once.
Thursday June 2d
I am on guard to day. Heavy firing at the front. Wrote a letter for Pete Berg. Jumped some this evening.
Friday June 3d
Hard fighting going on at the front today wounded are coming in report success. We struck tents to march once to day

but the order was counter-manded
Saturday June 4th
We moved camp, received orders to be ready to march at five oclock in the morn.
Sunday June 5th
We escorted a train to near Coal Harbor. Camped for the night. About 9 oclock at night there was a fight just out in front of us.
Monday June 6th
Returned to White House, The weather is warm, and marching disagreeable. I received a letter from Decker, the Avroposes(?) ad

-ventures for next winter I do not quite like his plan, although I confess it has many attractions.  I held a conversation with Imson and Berdan they both prefer going to school next Winter.
Tuesday June 7th
I wrote to Decker stating my objections to his plan and making many proposals myself. We went on picket this evening. Our post is on the left near the River.  The day is beautiful.

Wednesday June 8th
We were relieved just at dark and returned to camp where we received a whiskey ration.  I then held a council with Imson we think of attending the Gettysburg seminary this winter.  The day we have spent as usual on picket. reading sleeping and eating.
Thursday June 9th
Am fatigue, carrying wounded aboard the boat. I am utterly sick of such scenes. Also tired with the labor. What consolation do I get? Simply that we now have marching orders.

Oh that this cruel war was over.
Friday June 10th
We marched about sun down last evening. Kept on the march until near two this morn. I was so sleepy during the latter part of the march that  I often fell asleep in the ranks. Awake just after daylight. after breakfast we moved into the woods and stayed until the afternoon.  A beautiful woods, is this. H. and I ramble through it during the day. After noon we reported to army headquarters.

and were assigned to the second corp. reported to corp head quarters. and were ordered to the second divission. Went into the woods, while the Captain went to find division head quarters. When he returned we were permitted to lay down and sleep all night which was a welcome [gift] announcement.
Saturday June 11th
Awake just after daylight, our brigade being on the first line. We have not joined them yet.

Coleman came over to see us this morning. My heroic friend Archibald has at last been wounded. A minne(?) ball passed through his thigh. The inevitable Old Luke Fisher has also been hurt. A shell broke his highly prized pipe and injured his jaw at the same time. Picket firing is going on all the time. And shells are frequently exchanged.
Sunday June 12th
We joined the old brigade last night. The enemy threw

a few shell just about 40 rods to the right of our brigade.  They held meeting to day which I noticed was more largely attended than such meetings were wont to be in more quiet times.  Is the dangers of the situation the cause of this change?  One of the 7th Mich(?) was here to day giving an account of the late battles.  We are now (nearly sundown) under marching orders.
Monday June 13th
Just after sundown last night. We fell back

into the least advanced of our nines of works. and lay until quite late in the night while the more advanced lines were withdrawn after which we marched off.  While we lay in the works, we had an opportunity to watch some mortar practice, the first I ever saw the enemy were shelling a portion of our lines at least a mile from the position ocupied by our brigade. Although we could rarely hear the sound(?)

of the mortars, yet the report of the shell was fell as heavy, and not unlike that of a rifled 10 pounder. The  course of the shell being nearly toward us made thier motion appear very slow something like the ball of a spark of fire.  We moved slow during the night, just a day light on the 13th there came near being a panic! occassioned by a horse falling off of a bank into the road.
We arrived at Longs Bridge

just after eight in the morning and disembarked for a few hours. about two we left and crossed the Chica hominy. We found here some Cypress I picked a few leaves and intend to send them to Mother.  We guarded the rear and reached camp near Charles City Court House just about midnight.
Tuesday 14th We moved to nearer the C.H. this morning. Imsom and I visited the old building found it entirely

empty.  When our army passed this place in 62. They carried of all the rcords as trophies among them were documents in the hand writing of both Patrick Henry and John Randolph. The country here is open and very beautiful. In August 1862, We lived very highly while passing through this part of the Penninsula. I the afternoon we marched down to the James river and crossed on the U.S. Steam transport

Helen Getty. While on the dock Gen. U.S. Grant coming of the boat passed through our battalion.  The country on this side of the James is very beautiful we passed a field of corn which was the heaviest I have seen this year.  We go out to the front and lay in line of battle during the night. I was on guard / Written on the morn of the 15th.
1st day of the siege of Petersburg
Wednesday ___ A.M. 
We marched about 11 am and about 11 P.M.

we arrived in front of Petersburg. found that our men had taken three lines of the enemies work during the afternoon. / 2d day of the siege
Thursday June 16th
We dug rifle pitts during the latter part of last night. The enemies works here were very strange the darkies(?) charged and took them but no prisoners with them so I am told. A little shelling and skirmishing is kept up during the day. I am very sleepy and tired. Feel miserable but I can afford to bear hardships when there

is an end in view.  At 6 P.M. our fources advanced on the enemy and drove them some distance at the present time 7 P>M> there is a lull. We lay as reserve in our pitts as yet. 
Friday morning June 17th 3d day of the siege. Last night after dark I went on detail to draw rations and did not get back until one A.M. Our forces drove the enemy out of two lines of rifle pitts.  The enemy afterwards made two charges to drive them

back but were repulsed. Evening. There was some hard fighting on the left to day it is said that Burnside was successful in taking three forts Late in the evening the Rebs charged on our men again but were again repulsed. there is a movement going on but our brigade still remains in the breast works.
Saturday June 18th 4th day of the siege. We massed before daylight this morning and charged but found the first line of the enemies works vacated we pressed forward about three fourths of a mile. here

We found them awaiting use and drove them out another line of pitts after a time our battalion was deployed as skirmishes and had some hot(?) work we got a good position behind one of those old fuse tranches peculiar to the State of Virginia but owing to the recklessness of some of our men we had two men killed and one Officer (Lieut. Terrel) and five men wounded the enemy were very close and brave(?) too when drove there but we soon drove them of this we accomplish

without any support to our right flank. our recruits are splendid soldiers. after the 6th Corp. came up to support our right flank we advanced and gained another good position about 40 rods from a stray line of the enemies works and here we are shooting at rebs and the at us some of the 6th Corp charged on our right and part of our corp charged on the left of us but both failed we are now very close to the town of Peterburg but a mail to night

and Hezekiah received a letter informing him that Ned was hired out for thirty five dollars a month to go through with Sullies Indian expedition. Thus we are scattered.
Sunday June 19th 5th day of siege
We lay in our old position, have good rifle pitts, fire extensively but I do not suppose we have hurt many of them.  They also have fired a great deal no one has been inhured in our battalion up to the present hour. (6:30 P.M). I have slept considerable to day.

Monday morning
splendid(?) mortar practice
There was some kind of a fight on our left last night about 10 oclock.
Monday morning June 20th 6th day of siege
One of our recruits said when he enlisted he heard nothing but $300 bounty but now he heard nothing but bullets. The enemy open batteries enplading our lines. Our batteries also enplade other parts of their lines. Our boys are at work on new pitts to protect them from the emplading fire. Less picket firing to day

than yesterday in front of our battallion but the 19th Maine(?) having a flanking fire on the Rebel works in a certain place kept a continued fusilade upon it. I suspect it was rather annoying to the poor Reb soldiers for in my experience an enplading fire is the most to be dreaded. That a citizen may more thoroughly understand why this is so I will give the nature of such fire: while in rifle pitts we are protected in front by the earth thrown up from the pitt but suppose the line

___ is on our flank. what is to cover us?  moreover if a bullet coming from the front is to high it is harmless but one from the flank goes on until it finally falls among the men. The day has been beautiful and up to the present hour 7 P.M. Before has been no casualties in our battalion. But within sight of us just to the right they are carrying men to the rear all the time. this in front of the 6th corps.

7th day of the siege
June 21st
Tuesday morning. We were relieved from the trenches last night by a part of the 6th Corp. and Depart from 10 P.M. evening until late in the morning. We had just ____ our tents when the order came to pack up and we were soon on the move. The weather was very warm and the dust intolerable. I have just made up my mind that one day of war is more to be deplored than a whole ages of ordinary evils.  I shall do all in my power

to discourage war ever after this. Just about 4 oclock this afternoon we came upon the enemy lost two men in our battallion by sharpshooter. Oh! I am sick of war. God save me that I may oppose this slaughtering of human beings. Night Another man wounded in the battalion thus are we going. I was on __idette this night and several bullets struck in the earth in front

of the little pitt where I was posted. Our men worked nearly all night on rifle pitts.
Wednesday June 22 8th day of siege
Lay in our rifle pitts the 29th Maine lose men all the time by sharp shooters. A little after noon the enemy open a battery enfilading our pitts.  This battery is in a storng fort and a commanding position. I am still more disgusted with war. I wish this cruel war was over.
Evening.
Why have I felt so heavily for a few days?

The enemy have broken the left flank of the line and standing in the trenches too long was taken a prisoner. The skirming process so often discribed by returned prisoners was carried out to the letter.  After geing well skirmed we were taken to Petersburg and loged in an old brick build[ing?] which was former used for God know what. Of course there was great rejoicing over the arrival of a few Yanks in town. And some of

our men tried to curry favor by abusing the Government. Three of our Company are with me.
Thursday June 23d
Well I suppose my history of the siege has come to an untimely end, and the history of my imprisonment will now be the next thing in order. We formed a junction with a large number of other prisoners that were taken last night but had come another ways. There

we found several of our battalion.  The following are the names
Sergt Major Pride
Sergt May. Co. A
Sergt(?) Dyae Co. B
Corp. Clark Co. A
Corp. Leonard  Co. A
Corp. Reed  Co. A
Corp. Alpus  Co. A
Corp. Irvine Co. A
Corp. Bond Co. B
Privates
Prible Co. A
Perkins Co. A
Carpenter Co. A
Baker Co. A
Rider Co. A
Harvey Co. A

Perg Co. B
Parker Co. B
Hamilton Co. B
Sullivan Co. B
Abraham Co. B
Whallen Co. B
Stacloth Co. B
Passed through the City of Petersburg this morn. It is somewhat ahead of most southern Cities but the inevitiable dirty brick buildings still prevail. One feature is the Great number of ____ (shade?) trees.  I love this peculiarity.  The women

were in ecstacies over the yankey prisoners. But when we halted for a time they kindly brought water with even being asked for it. This shall be remembered to their credit.  Our names were taken. We bathed in the Appomatox and lay around the place is not so shady as I should like we are on a kind of island withing hearing of our artilery. There are in all about 1200.
They called the names

of about 800. Who were to be sent off to Richmond tomorrow.
Friday June 24th about 2 oclock this morning we were called up and marched down to the depot where we took the cars and arrived in Richmond about 12 oclock. Here a still more rigid search is going on. All greenbacks must go to the way of all living
We are at the famous Libly prison. One good thing the floors are clean

and spit boxes are plentiful. We draw this evening two pieces of corn bread about 5 inches long, 1-1/2 thick; and two wide. This bread is made without salt How long these trophies are expected to last us I do not know.
Saturday June 25th
They issue to us a small piece of bacon another piece of bread same size as those issued last night and half pint of bean soup with plenty of beans in it.

I read in the Testament I have done so every day since I was taken prisoner and if the Lord so will it I shall continue to do so untill I am free. I have a grammer also and I hope to be able to study that some. But up to the present time I have been making up lost sleep.  Our names and places of birth were taken to day. It is rumored that we are to be paroled.  I would be glad to get away

from here.
Sunday June 26th
I read in the Testament. I have come to the conclusion that the bread which we receive here will weight about a pound though from its bulk it ought not to weigh more than half that amount.  We were removed to Belle Island.  Here we received old miserably worn wedge and Bell tent.  I will not tell a single thing worse than the truth.  We were permitted to take a good bath in

the James river. I read in the Testament study grammer. We are divided into messes of fifty, and ten in each tent.
Monday June 27th
Our rations of bread not quite so large as formerly but a little better quality, more soup but not so many beans in it. less meat and of a very poor quality. I eat mine all at one meal and could have eaten twice as much our coffee has not entirely given out yet.  And

we have a little of Uncle Sams pork yet. Read in the Testament, Study Grammer and sleep.
Tuesday June 28th
It rained last night and the tent leaked miserably. Afterwards the wind arose and the tent blew over.  I read in the Testament, study grammer, and sleep. rations the same except soup of which we received a double quantity.
Wednesday June 29th
We drew the usual amount of bread and meat

but no soup.  We then moved off got aboard the cars and started for Lynchburg.  The cars were miserably crowded and no water. we arrived in L. about 12 Midnight having been about 18 hours on the way. Morning of the 30th we did not get off the cars until after daylight this morning. We then crossed onto an Island and are here yet. have not drawn any more rations yet but I traded my portfolios for a piece of corn bread and my

gold pen for a quart of meal so I am not suffering. I had neglected to state that one of the prisoners leaped off the cars last night and although he was twice fired at he escaped unhurt, God speed him to our lines.
Thursday June 30th
We drew hard bread rations said to be for four days; eighteen crackers considerably thicker than an uncle Sam hard bread; some what mouldy. We also drew some bacon which was quite good albeit wormy. We left Lynchburg

H. Stackliff gave out to day
about 4 P.M. in marching through the Town I observed that the streets were dirty and rough. Lynchburg is situated amid mountains and hills.  There are a great many hospitals here Several of which are filled with wounded from our army. I noticed one very fine building on the heights, south of the town: this building is at present used as a hospital. What it formerly was I know not. I noticed that Gen.

Hunter in his late advances had crossed the James river and approached within a mile and a half of the place from the south side we passed over ground where some of the fighting had taken place. I read some in the Testament today.
Friday July 1st 1864
We camped last night in a good place about 5 miles from Lynchburg. The country is hilly and mountainous, resembling Loudon Valley. The same may be said of the country we passed

through during the fore noon to day. Afternoon the country became more level some of the scenery is beautiful. Land here is very poor.  We camped at night on a river said to be the Stanton River. distance marched 20 miles
Saturday July 2d
Marched about 20 miles camped in a nice place by the side of a brook. The guards were giving out so fast to day that they had to call out the citizens to guard

us. The country much the same as that we passed yesterday.
Sunday July 3d
Distance marched about 15 m. Passed through Pittsylvania C.H. A nicely shaded town. I had the hardest fight to day I have had in my life. A sort of drawn fame. I am hurt the worst of the two but I gained my point. I learn since the fight that I had hold of a bully.  We have been passing through Pittsylvania C.H. I think

for the last two days.
Danville July 4th 1864
We arrived here to day and were crowded into prisons.  The town is situated on a broad, though shallow and ricky river. Have not received any ration yet to night. Although the time for drawing came last night. I think we will get some yet tonight.  The distance we marched to day was 16 miles.
Mr. Whallin gave out to day. A ____ I shall live

morning of the 5th we drew bread and meat after dark last night more of it and better quality than that which we received a Belle Island or Libby and again this morn we received bread.  As our march is not ended I will state before leaving the subject that several have escaped. many were fired at, but few if any were hit. The weather has been warm.
Evening of July 5th Tuesday
We drew bread yet again today and a larger

quantity than ever before. I read in the Testament and study grammer. Later we took the cars for Greenburg and then we cross guard for Charlotte.
Wednesday July 6th 
We arrived in Charlotte about 12 m. to day and here we are. drew three days rations of hard bread and bacon.
Thursday July 7th
We were called up about midnight last night and moved(?) into the cars but we did not leave Charlotte until

eight this morn. passed through a Johnathan(?) they're slaves to Columbia
Friday July 8th Changed cars about midnight and to day we came through to Augusta Georgoa
Saturday July 9th
We lay in Augusta until afternoon when we got aboard the cars and ___ved off
Sunday July 10th
Passed through Macon this morn and arrived at the camp. A miserable place it is Found Sam Wales

Monday July 11th
Lay arround, read in the Testament. Six ruffians ____ named(?)
Tuesday July 12th
Cloudy and therefore pleasant. Have the Diarrhea, read the Testament and lay around
Wednesday July 13th
Lay arround and read the Testament Talk with Sam Wales this evening
Thursday July 14th
The force(?) guard(?) ___ seem very uneasy to day. I read in the Testament and lay around
Friday July 15th
Read the Testament

Saturday
July 16th
Read the Testament.
Sunday July 17th
Read in the Testament. A traitor was punished severly to day by our boys for betraying a plot to escape
Monday July 18th
Read in the Testament. Rained.
Tuesday July 19th 
Read the Testament.
Wednesday July 20th
Rebs get scared and fortifying(?). I read the Testam[ent]
Thursday July 21st
Read in the Testament
Friday July 22d
read in the Testament.

Saturday July 23d
Read in the Testament.
Sunday July 24th
Cold enough this morning to make the boys put on thier coats. pretty well for Georgia in July. read in the Testament.
Monday July 25th 
Read the Testament and study Grammers
Tuesday 26th
Read in the Testament and Study Grammer. Rained.
Wednesday July 27th
Read in the Testament and Study Grammer.

Thursday July 28th
Mr. Starcliff returned.
Read in the Testament. bathe. A large number of prisoners came in from Shermans army. The rebs fired a shot over our heads to intimidate us. Rained.
Friday July 29th
Read in the Testament. Rained. More prisoners come in some with an arm off and the wounds not yet healed.
Saturday July 30th
Read in the Testament.

Sunday July 31st
Sergt. Major. doesn't know that Sunday is the 1st day of the week.  One man absent from roll call stoped(?) his rations. Read in the Test-
Monday Aug. 1st 1864
Read in the Testament.
A great deal of talk about parole. Rained a little.
Tuesday Aug. 2d
Read in the Testament.
Rained hard to day. Some of Stonemans cavelry were brought in to day.
Wednesday Aug. 3th
They are removing the sick. more of the cavelry

were brought in.
Thursday Aug. 4th
Read in the Testament. More reports about parole yesterday and today they have removed some of the sick
Friday Aug. 5th
Read in the Testament
Saturday Aug. 6th
Read Psalms and Testament. draw an extra ration of meal to night.
Sunday Aug. 7th
Read Psalms. Found Wm. Daily and Epriam Tomson of the 5th Ind. Cavelry. Great rumors of parole

Lost our bread ration to night.
Monday Aug. 8th
Read Psalms, rained, bathed
Tuesday Aug. 9th
A very hard rain, part of the Stockade fell down which gave the rebels great trouble.  Read psalms no rations to day.
Wednesday Aug. 10th
Half rations of bread and some beans this morn. Nothing night but fresh beef and salt. Rained again to day.  Read Psalms - Quarrel

and fight between two of our boys. H. and P.
Thursday Aug. 11th
Part rations, Rained hard again. Read in Psalms. Admire the fifty fifth very much.
Friday Aug. 12th
Read Psalms and also Christs sermon on the mount. Rations continue short
Saturday Aug. 13th
Read Psalms and also in the New Testament, more rumors of parole. provisions continue scarse. A few men(?) were flogged to day.

Sunday Aug. 14th 1864. 
More extensive rumors of parole.  Read Psalms.
Monday Aug. 15th Read Psalms. Rumors die away.
Tuesday Aug. 16th
Read Psalms
Wednesday Aug. 17th
I read psalms went to sick call to see how horrible it realy is and Oh! my God. I hope a parole will relieve(?) this wretchedness.  I was also on detail to draw rations. Rumors steady

Found Bill Smith formerly(?) of the 34th N.Y.
Thursday Aug. 18th
Market prices as follows
Bread per ration 10 cts
Beans per ration 10 cts
Beef per ration 10 cts
Bacon very scarce 20 El 25' (?)
Beer per cup  5 cts
Soda water per cup  5 cts
Sassparila syrup per cup 10 cts

Boiled Eggs 25 each
Brisquit Butter 25 cts each
corn meal coffee 10 cts per cup
Large yellow tomatoes 30 and 40 each

Onions per bunch(?)  75 cts

Corn Brusquit  5 cts

White Peas  25 cts pint
Potatoes small 1.00 per doz
Flour  50 ct per pint
Nearly all trade is carre
the sale currency green backs. Postage Stamps at one ct. a piece. Confederate money does not pass well. I read psalms during the day. managed to get hold of an oak pole and by trading I managed to increase my rations
Friday Aug. 19th
Visited the markets.

Rations same as yesterday
Potatoes $1.00 cts pint
Bean soup 5  about 4 spoonsful
Irish(?) molasses 5 per plate about 5 spoonsful
Rice(?)   10    "   "
White peas   25  "
Buisquit ___  butter   30
Apples apples 10, 20, 25 cts
Eggs 25 cts each
Bacon none in market
Meal 20 cts quart
Salt 5 cts spoonfuls
Pies 1.20
Red peppers 5 Pod
Soda  25 cts spoonful
Half canteen soda corn cakes 35 cts
Peaches 15 to 30 cts each
I saw large onions 25 ct each

I saw grapes in market but failed to learn the price owing to the owners being so gruff.  I saw a sick man laying the creek this morn. helped him out. Such scenes as this I am compelled to mention in a very casual manner leaving description for a fuller commentary at such future time.  Rained.
I read Psalms 127th. I despair(?) to remember.
Saturday Aug. 20th
Market prices.
Rations as yesterday except Bacon included(?)

(drew past rations last night of bacon.)
is not so high
Corn mean 20 cts quart
Rice  70 quart
Cooked rice  10 plate
Corn fritter 10 for 3
Wheat with Gravy  20  "  "
Boiled eggs, bisquit, bean soup, pease, soup, tobacco, same as yesterday
Peaches 10, 20, 25, 30
Tomatoes non in market
Watermellon  5cts per cut
Chickens $5 greenback per pair
One blanket $10  plat  20 cts
Rained again today. Saw the same sick man laying by the side of the creek this morn.  Read Psalms

Sunday Aug. 21st
Markets much the same as yesterday Bread 10 to 15 and Bacon 20 cts per ration. Finish reading Psalms. Rained again to day
Monday Aug. 22d
My time of service in the U.S. properly expires to day but I suppose that circumstances will extend it somewhat.  Read in the Testament.
Tuesday Aug. 23d
A good deal of trading with the guard. Read in the Testament.
Wednesday Aug. 24th 
Read in Testament.

Thursday Aug. 25th
Read in Testament. Change Ration system. hereafter the high detachments draw ran rations.
Friday Aug 26th
Bathed. Read in Test. on detail to draw rations
Saturday Aug. 27th
Read in Testament
Sunday Aug. 28th
Read in Testament
Monday Aug. 29th
Report that new parole has been agreed upon but that proposals have been sent to our(?)

government. No answer received yet.  Read in Testament.
Tuesday Aug. 30th
Read Testament. Here I desire to note the peculiar fact that a dead man is valued in this camp as a means of obtaining wood. For those who carry out the dead can bring back an armful of wood.  From one to three dollars worth of wood can be thus obtained by each individual who is lucky enough to have a dead comrade

1864
Wednesday Aug. 31st
Read Testament. One of the features of this camp is contraband trade between the prisoners and guard.
Thursday Sept 1st 1864
Went over and visited the boys of the 9th Reg. Read in Testament
Friday Sept. 2d
Read Testament and visited the boys of the 9th and Second 2nd cavalry. Many have high hopes of a speedy exchange
Saturday Sept. 3d
Read in the Testament. Rumors of a battle and

Sept.
victory on the old field of Fair Oaks.
Sunday Sept. 4th
Read in the Testament. Great rumors of fighting and victories. The name of this prison is Camp Sumpter near Andersonville GA.
Monday Sept 5th
Some prisoners come in from Shermans army reporting victory to ___ arms. More parole stories. Read in the Testament
Tuesday Sept. 6th
Read in the Test-  18 Detachments ___

orders to be ready to leave here at a moments notice. Said to be for exchange. There are in this prison 118 Detachments each detachment has 3 messes and each mess is supposed to contain 90 men.
Wednesday Sept. 7th.
Sic detachments left here today. I read in the Testament.
Thursday Sept. 8th
More men leave, Hope to God it may be an exchange.
Read in the Testament.

1864
Friday Sept 9th
Read in the Testament. More prisoners go out. rations _____ short.
Saturday 10th Sept.
On detail to draw rations got very near full rations more men leave this horrid place.  Our detachment has orders to be in readiness to move. God speed the hour i read in the Testament.
Sunday Sept. 11th
Rather sleepy to day as I only slept two hours last night prisoners still ___

Monday Sept. 12th
Prisoners continue to leave Read in the Testament. All draw cooked rations over twenty detachments broke camp to day.
Tuesday Sept. 13th
More prisoners leave. Read in the Testament. An axcident on the Rail road to night.
Wednesday Sept. 14th
No prisoners leave to day on account of the axcident.
Thursday Sept. 15th
No prisoner leave to day. Except a

few sick
Friday Sept. 16th
Part of the sick that went out last night return.
Saturday Sept. 17th
Every thing seems to drag. After dark ____ they took out 700 of Shermans men to the exchange at Atlanta / so reported Ft. _________
Monday 18th Friday [Stricken: no prisoners leave] prospect begins to look gloomy. Rained. Read Testament. [Stricken: More of Shermans men go out to]

[Stricken: night] Monday [Stricken: Tuesday] 19th Sept.
More of Shermans men leave to night. Read in the Testament.
Tuesday 20th
An order for all _ilo__ to give in their names.  Read Testament
Wednesday 21st Sept. 
Dark and rainy, has been cloudy and gloomy ever since the 18th. Read in the Testament. Prisoner(?) hard bread what is going happen?
Thursday Sept. 22nd
Rained. Read in the Test.
____________________________

Reorganize the Testament (?)
I have a very bad cold with sore throat lately.
Friday 23rd
Rained. Read Testament
Saturday 24th 
Rained.
Sunday 25th Sept.
Wonderful Cold last night. My gums are eaten out with the scurvy
Monday Sept. 26th
Very cold last night
Tuesday Sept. 27th
They took out some more prisoners last night.
[Stricken: Wednesday Oct. 23]

Wednesday Sept. 28th
a few more prisoners go out to night.
Thursday Sept 29th
I suffer constantly now with Scurvy
Friday Sept. 30th
As usual, nothing but dreary imprisonment
Saturday Oct. 1st 1864
Here we lay in our misery
Sunday Oct 2d
Read in Description of Africa
Monday Oct. 3d
Red "Country Cousins" and description of Africa.

1864
Tuesday Oct. 4th
Read in Description of Africa 
Wednesday Oct. 5th
Read in Description of Africa and in The Last leaf from Sunny(?) Side.
Thursday Oct. 6th
Read in Description of Africa. Rained.
Oct. 7th Friday
Failed to get out to night
Saturday Oct. 8th
No prisoners leave to day. very cold.
Sunday Oct. 9th
Reorganize the

detachments. Very cold.
Monday Oct. 10th
3 months since we first came to this camp. Nights are cold.
Tuesday Oct. 11th
Prisoners arrive from Shermans army 14th and 15th Ill Regts are now the number ones
Wednesday Oct. 12th
All as usual. Read in the Testament (Lets draw buisquit)
Thursday Oct. 13th
On detail to draw rations night continue cold
Friday Oct. 14th
Visited the sick . Lay arround

Saturday Oct. 15th 
Rebel papers claim a victory at Altoona. Five men out of every hundred permitted to go out for wood.
Sunday Oct. 16th
Read in the Testament.
Monday Oct. 17th
As usual every thing is dull and monotonous.
Tuesday Oct. 18th
Read in Robinson fred We went out for wood.
Wednesday Oct., 19th 
Went out

for wood. Read in Robinson Crusoe
Thursday Oct. 20th
Read Robinson Crusoe
Friday Oct. 21st
Went out for wood. Read phrenology and physiognomy
Saturday Oct. 22d
All quiet nothing worth mentioning
Sunday Oct. 23d
Nothing 
[Stricken: Sunday Oct]
Monday Oct. 24th
Every thing is dull.
Tuesday 25th Oct.
Work on our shantry.

Wednesday Oct. 26th 
Reports ofexchange.
Thursday Oct. 27th
Rained pretty hard.
Friday Oct. 28th
Reports that we are going to another prison - sold my ____ to Hamilton.
Saturday Oct. 29th
As usual nothing worth recording
Sunday Oct. 30th
Received orders to be ready to move out in the morning.
Monday Oct. 31st

MARGINALIA:

Cold, clear in the morning, cloudy and cold in the evening Commence work trying to fix for winter. My(?) time looks gloomy.

Sick going out again. I saw a man sell his last rations of beans for five cents and then go and bet, and lose it on a church luck board.

Take out sick gain to day.

Some men have been killed for the purpose of getting exchanged by taking their names. They are making out a list of the oldest prisoners to day.
Monday Nov. 21st
Got orders to fall in at one A.M. and after an inconceivable amount of crowding we got out at the gate and got aboard the cars. this was

accomplished through a rain storm. We got a cracker and half- and about half lb of beef for one days ration. Rolled off to Savannah where we were put aboard flat cars and run on all this night of storm and wind. We are now on the morn of the 22d about eighty miles south of Savannah. I think we must be near Brunswick.
Tuesday Nov. 22d
We lay by the side of the rail Road

have tolerable fires but nothing to eat. Weather clear and cold. windy. My pants and blouse you may judge are poor since they have been worn ever since last February constant wear. I have no blanket of my own, but one shirt that I can wear. And that is more than a year old. No socks, but I am in luck to have a good pair of shoes.
Wednesday Nov. 23d
We got a pretty good

ration of hard bread but nothing with it. Weather clear, cold, and windy.

move out into the roads, draw a few hard bread
Friday Nov. 25th
Nothing much going on
Saturday Nov. 26th
Took out a thousand prisoners and paroled them

A stoppage in the parole.

Run round and trade with the guard whereby I got a little to eat.

Take out another thousand to day.

One man shot by the guard.

Nothing worthy of note, only remarkably fine weather for winter.

The thousand that went out last returned to day having been to

Saturday Dec. 3d
We draw two day rations
I read in the Testament
Sunday Dec. 4th
I read in the Testament. There is some clothing here which has been sent from our lines. I do not blame the naked men who have taken the

oath of allegiance to the south. for many of them would now have been in their graves had they remained in prison.
Monday Dec. 5th
They take out 1600 men to day. Read in the Testament
Tuesday Dec. 6th
They undertook to issue the days rations to day but failed for want of material. They likewise reorganized the hundreds.
Wednesday Dec. 7th
Rained. and we fool about rations all day. Spent most of the day drawing beef

Many of our men are escaping nowadays.
Thursday Dec. 8th
I fell very feverish to day. The water is not good here.
Friday Dec. 9th
I feel unwell all day.  Several hundred have orders to be ready to go out.
Saturday Dec. 10th
We broke up camp and went over to the depot. The Rebels had a good time of burning yanks out of their hiding places before leaving

camp. Cold rain tonight.
Sunday Dec. 11th
got aboard the cars and after a good deal of trouble got off south and westward. we were crowded 85 men in one small car. Chivalry
Monday Dec. 12th
We arrived at Thomasville and got into the new camp at 3 A.M. this morn. Weather cold and windy. We got out and got a little wood about noon.
Tuesday De. 13th
pas the day rather uselessly. reorganize the camp.

Get a few loads of pine burs to burn.
Thursday Dec. 15th
I read Pauls Epistle to Titas.
Friday Dec. 16th
The papers bring ?auralcorint? of fighting and raiding near Savanah also fo hard fighting near Nashville caiming a Rebel victory. Reorganize the hundreds.
Saturday Dec. 17th
Issue two days rations of hard bread with

a canteen to keep them on hand. This looks something like leaving.
Sunday Dec. 18th
Read Pauls Epistle to Titas. Reports are rife that Savanah has fallen into the hands of Sherman.
Monday Dec. 19th
We leave camp a little after six oclock and marched from fight to ten miles in a northernly direction crossed one river the name of which I do not know. marching is very

Tuesday Dec. 20th
march sixteen miles drizzle rain. Very tired.
Wednesday Dec. 21st
Cold windy and ___(cloudy?)  very bad roads
Thursday Dec. 22d
Clear cold and windy. march sixteen miles
Friday Dec. 23d
marched two miles. Lay in camp until after dark when we went down to Albany and got aboard the cars

Cars started about 3 A.M. and we arrived at old camp Sumpter before noon. Prospect gloomy

A miserable time. Rained. Such an awful Christmas

To all whom it may concern
Be it known, that this Testimonial of regard is given to Daniel Bond of "F" Company 1st Minnesota Vol Infty on the occasion of my leaving the military service of the US under a sence of Justice to a Brave + faithful soldier.
Having been under my immediate Command since the 16th day of September 1862 to the present time it is proper for me to say Daniel Bond has during that time been ever anxious to meet the enemies of his government, and whose merits are best seen through the smoke of Battle.
Fort Snellin Minn
May 5th 1864
John Ball
Capt. Comdg "F" Compnay
1st Minnesota Vol. Infty

Names of persons mentioned in this book.
1. Samson, Pelatial, Hezekiah, Benjamin, Edward (Ned), my brothers.
2. Archabald, Barnes. Coleman. Were boys under sixteen years of age belonging to the second companh of Minnesota sharpshooters and were attached to our regiment as Co. L. Archabald was not fifteen years old, small of his age, looked like a pretty little dark-eyed girl.  He was so young and small that he had to enlist as a drummer.  But he refused to drum and demanded his rifle, proving himself to be an excellent marksman, he had his way.  These boys served their full time all were wounded but all got safely home at least.  They lived near Lake Minnetonka and I had some acquaintance with them before the war. Truer steel was never yet put into men.
3. Standish - Decker - recruits who enlisted at the same time I did.  Standish was a good boy twenty years old son of a Methodist Preacher - his family of the Old Massachusetts stock.  He himself was born in Massachusetts. When the war broke out he was a student air(?) Hamline University. So also were Phillip Hamlin and Charles Berdan students and sons of Methodist preachers. Hamlin was killed at Gettysburg. So far as I know Berdan is living yet. He was twice wounded. There were, perhaps, a dozen more students of the university - among the Seargent Wright with whom I came most in contact and most admired. I think it can safely be said that all these students gave a good account of themselves.
4. "Jarve" Jarvis Chaffee a young man who in 1859 had his right arm and scalp torn off in my fathers threshing machine. It was several years before the sore scalp healed.  Meanwhile it would inflame whenever he tried to study.  We kept him in our home the greater part of the time for two years.  I became much attached to him and from letters I wrote him I have been able to supplement much of what would have been lost with my Diary which I lost July 30, 1862 at the Battle of White Oak swamps.
5. "Melissa," Melissa Bond a cousin of mine who had lived several years in our family. She was teaching in Indiana during the war.
